repnme.cdata!: Costa Rica - Transport Sector Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact is high. Lessons convey primarily, that
            in spite of difficult times - after a decade of economic
            slowdown, fiscal deficits, and progressive inflation - such
            times can indeed promote change: sectoral reforms could be
            achieved, although change was slow, but the lengthy process
            resulted in a stronger transport sector, with policies
            focused on efficiency, achieving institutional restructuring
            of sector authorities. And, in spite of added complexities
            to project implementation, such as the number of
            institutions involved, the sectoral analysis on each
            sub-sector, provided a better understanding of institutional
            needs. Notably, the project improved the planning capacity
            for road maintenance, and investments, demonstrating how a
            planning capacity requires a dependable source of funding to
            sustain investment programs. The road, and highway
            sub-sectors, supported by financial resources, is in a
            privileged position to confront the national network
            maintenance acceptably. However, this sub-sector still faces
            the task of improving road conditions, which should be
            challenged by providing sound policies, and optional plans
            to meet sector objectives. Regarding the railways
            sub-sector, assistance in rationalizing its operations was
            provided through a continuous management support, and, with
            the concession law of 1998, a new concession process has
            been initiated, with prospects for cargo remaining positive.
            Renewed interest in the decentralization of cantonal roads,
            stirred the Bank's interest to support a new operation.
            But, it is important to note the need to streamline the
            procurement process, so as to gain operational efficiency,
            and avoid frequent construction delays.

5078941.trustfund:
TF036250-LAC REGION  - TRANSPORT SECTOR
            (HONDURAS, COSTA RICA, GUATEMALA)

abstracts.cdata!:
The project supports institutional
            measures to increase the efficiency of the sector.  Main
            institutional measures call for scaling down the railway,
            designing a strategy for the maintenance of cantonal roads,
            improving port operations and encouraging increased
            participation of the private sector. Strengthening meausures
            consist of technical assistance and training for : a)
            developing a transport plan; b) tariff evaluation, setting
            and costing; c) implementing a pavement management system;
            d) improving information management in JAPDEVA; e)
            implementing a plan to rationalize railway services in
            INCOFER; and f) mid-level managment training.  The physical
            components are : 1) rehabilitation and upgrading of trunk
            roads in the import export corridors; 2) periodic main roads
            maintenance; 3) replacement of the Puntarenas jetty; 4)
            equipment and tools for road maintenance and safety,
            pavement management; 5) information systems in MOPT,
            INCOFER, INCOP, and JAPDEVA; 6) grain handling operations in
            the port of Calderas; 7) control of in-transit cargo; 8)
            rail track maintenance; and 9) engineering and supervision services.
